Catalytic combustion is a highly efficient technology for reducing VOCs, and the development of monolithic catalysts with superior catalytic activity suitable for industrial applications is crucial. In this study, a novel MnOx/copper mesh (CM) monolithic catalyst was prepared for toluene oxidation using a one-step electrodeposition method. The effect of deposition conditions on the catalytic performance of MnOx/CM monolithic catalysts was systematically investigated by varying the deposition time, electrolyte concentration and deposition voltage. Due to good low-temperature reducibility and higher Mn4+ and Olatt content, the T50 % and T90 % of 1.24–0.2 MnOx/CM-60 catalyst could reach 229 °C and 242 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the catalyst exhibited excellent water tolerance, cycling and long-term stability. In-situ DRIFTS analysis confirmed a possible degradation pathway in which lattice oxygen in the catalyst oxidized the adsorbed toluene molecules to form intermediates (benzyl alcohol and benzoate). Subsequent replenishment of gaseous oxygen (involving oxygen vacancy creation-disappearance) led to aromatic ring breakage and the intermediates were further oxidized to maleate and finally to CO2 and H2O. This study provides a reference for the in-situ construction of low-cost metal-based monolithic catalysts for VOCs catalytic oxidation. Graphical abstract This paper reported a novel and simple approach for preparation of MnOx/CM monolithic catalyst with excellent toluene catalytic oxidation perform Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnOx Copper mesh, Monolithic catalyst Toluene oxidation Electrodeposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are characterized by easy diffusion, high toxicity and high volatility, widely present in chemical production, industrial exhaust, paint spraying, and other industries [1]. They are crucial precursors to ozone and fine particulate matter, leading to environmental problems and posing serious hazards to human health [2-5]. Based on this, various VOCs end-treatment technologies such as adsorption [6,7], membrane separation [8,9], biological degradation [10], plasma [11], photo/photothermal catalytic decomposition [12,13] and catalytic combustion [14-16] have been developed. Catalytic combustion is an effective and reliable pathway of VOCs elimination [17], the key breakthrough is designing catalysts with high performance at low temperatures. Manganese oxides (MnOx) are widely used as economically effective catalysts in VOCs (particularly aromatics) oxidation due to their exceptional oxygen storage/release capacity and high activity [18]. To enhance catalytic activity and gain a deeper understanding of the structure-activity relationships, researchers have conducted numerous experiments focusing on designing morphologies [19,20], controlling crystal phases and facets [12,21], decorating with dopants [16,22,23], and exploring other aspects of manganese-based powder catalysts. However, these powder catalysts have limitations such as high-pressure drop, separation difficulties, and susceptibility to loss, which impede their practical industrial applications. In contrast, monolithic catalysts with a multi-channel structure are more suitable for practical industrial use [24]. These monolithic catalysts typically utilize ceramics, primarily cordierite, or metals such as stainless steel, alloys, or metal foam/mesh as support or substrate. Among these options, metal meshes such as iron mesh or copper mesh, offer a three-dimensional interconnected channel structure [25], providing strong mechanical stability, and superior mass and heat transfer capabilities compared to the commonly used cordierite-based substrates [26]. Therefore, metal meshes demonstrate significant potential for application. The loading of active components plays a crucial role in constructing monolithic catalysts, as it significantly influences their catalytic activity and lifespan. Currently, one commonly used methods for loading active components onto monolithic catalysts is in-situ growth techniques such as solvothermal [27,28] and electrochemical deposition [29]. Electrochemical deposition involves the use of an applied electric field to prepare materials in precursor solutions, offering a simple and controllable preparation process and resulting in a diverse range of products. These characteristics have led to its widespread application in the field of electrocatalysis, including the preparation of electrode materials [30-32] and supercapacitors [33-35]. Recent studies have highlighted the potential of this rapid and straightforward electrodeposition method as a synthetic strategy for monolithic catalysts used in thermal catalytic reactions, such as VOCs catalysis [29,36,37]. For instance, Wang et al. [29] deposited Co-Ce/nickel foam mixed oxide catalysts using the unipolar pulse electrodeposition (UPED) method, achieving complete degradation of toluene at 268 °C due to superior physiochemical properties, including abundant low-temperature reactive oxygen species and high oxygen vacancies concentration. Additionally, Wang et al. [36] creatively proposed alternating anode and cathode electrodeposition, successfully preparing a NiCo2O4-MnOx -NF monolithic catalyst which could reach 90 % benzene conversion at 196 °C. In this study, we employed a time-efficient and energy-saving one-step anodic constant voltage electrodeposition strategy to achieve in-situ growth of manganese oxides on cost-effective copper mesh. The reducibility, catalytic activity, water resistance, cycling performance and long-term stability of the prepared MnOx/CM monolithic catalysts were systematically investigated. In addition, in-situ DRIFTS technology was utilized to reveal the possible degradation pathway and oxidation mechanism of toluene on the catalyst surface. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Pretreatment of metal substrates: The copper metal substrates were pretreated with dilute acid before electrodeposition. The details are given in Supporting Information. Synthesis of MnOx/CM-t (t=10, 20, 40, 60, 80 min): A simple and rapid electrochemical approach was used to oxidize and deposit low-valence manganese ions on the substrate [34,36]. In this experiment, the three-electrode system was composed of a pretreated clean CM, a Pt sheet and an Ag/AgCl electrode, corresponding to the working, counter and reference electrodes, respectively. For the synthesis of catalyst MnOx/CM-60, 0.2 mol/L (Mn (CH3COO)2·4H2O) electrolyte and the aforementioned three electrodes were transferred to the electrolytic cell. An amperometric i-t curve method was used for constant voltage electrochemical deposition, with deposition parameters set to a voltage of 1.24 V for 60 min at room temperature. Following deposition, the sample was rinsed with deionized water for 10 s to clear out surface impurities and then dried in an oven at 60 °C. To enhance the adhesion between the substrate and the deposited components and improve the stability of catalysts, the MnO2/CM-60 sample mentioned above was calcined at 400 °C for 5 h to obtain MnOx/CM-60 catalyst. For comparison, the sample obtained by calcining the pretreated CM under the same calcination conditions was labeled as CuOx/CM. In addition, the catalyst preparation method involving different electrolyte concentrations and deposition voltages was similar to that of MnOx/CM-t. Specific details are available in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The physical properties (structural composition and surface morphology) and chemical properties (reducibility and surface chemistry) of the catalysts were analyzed using characterization techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in-situ DRIFTS. Specific details are given in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The prepared monolithic catalyst samples (2 cm × 9 cm) were tested for toluene performance on a fixed-bed micro-reaction evaluation device equipped with a gas flow meter and temperature controller. At the start of the test, a gas mixture (800 ppm C7H8, 20 vol % O2 and Ar balance) was introduced into the reactor (inner diameter was 10 mm) at a flow rate of 100 mL·min-1 (GHSV=15,000 h-1), while running the heating program (temperature range: room temperature to 400 °C, heating rate: 2 °C·min-1). Toluene concentration at the reactor outlet was determined using gas chromatography (GC7890B, Agilent), and the toluene conversion rate could be calculated by Eq. (1). Typically, T50 % and T90 % (representing the temperature at 50 % and 90 % toluene conversions, respectively) were employed as evaluation indices for catalyst activity. To evaluate the catalyst's cycling stability, continuous performance tests were conducted over five cycles. After each test, the fixed-bed reactor was held at 260 °C for 3 h and subsequently cooled to room temperature before the next cycle. The catalyst was subjected to a 44-hour toluene performance test to assess its long-term stability. Additionally, 5 % H2O was added to the gas composition to investigate the catalyst's tolerance to water. Specially, in the water resistance test, the actual water vapor content and toluene concentration in the outlet gas were monitored using FTIR (MKS-2000, Builder). (1) Toluene conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − C [ out ] C [ in ] ) × 100 % Where C[in] and C[out] are the concentration of toluene in the gas flow before and after the catalysts bed, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural and morphological properties Fig. 1 displays the XRD pattern of CM and MnOx/CM-t catalyst prepared by electrodeposition before and after calcination. Before calcination (Fig. 1a), except for the presence of copper, no characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to other phases were observed. To eliminate the influence of the substrate, surface powder was scraped from the deposited copper mesh for phase analysis. Taking MnOx/CM-60 as an example, Fig. 1b exhibits two weak peaks at 37° and 66.2°, corresponding to the (100) and (110) crystal planes of ε-MnO2 (JCPDS 30–0820) [38]. This indicated successful in-situ loading of MnO2 onto the CM substrate using the anodic electrodeposition method. The formation process is illustrated in Scheme 1 . During electrodeposition, Mn2+ in the electrolyte migrated to the electrode surface through diffusion and electric field drive, and the positive voltage was applied to promote its oxidation on the anode surface, resulting in Mn2++2H2O→MnO2+4H++2e- reaction [39]. Subsequently, MnO2 (typically ε-MnO2) began to nucleate and grow [34,40]. After calcination (Fig. 1c), apart from the characteristic diffraction peaks of copper, copper oxide species such as Cu2O and CuO originating from the CM were observed. Previous studies suggested that the formation of copper oxides was likely due to the high-temperature oxidation of Cu0 on the substrate surface [41,42]. Additionally, the peaks at 31.4° and 32.8° could be attributed to the (200) and (103) crystal planes of Mn3O4 (JCPDS No. 24–0734), respectively [43]. However, no obvious MnO2 diffraction peaks were observed in the XRD pattern. This result could be explained by the small particle size and high dispersion of MnO2 or its presence as an amorphous phase generated through electrodeposition [27,36,44]. As the deposition time increased, the relative intensity of copper oxide diffraction peaks decreased, indicating some increase in the manganese oxide formed on the substrate. However, the catalysts prepared at different deposition times exhibited essentially the same phase structure, and similar results were observed in catalysts with changes in other parameters, such as electrolyte concentration and deposition voltage (Fig. S1). This suggested that the deposition conditions within the experimental range did not have a major influence on the structural composition of the monolithic catalysts. The SEM images in Fig. 2 depict the surface morphology of CM, CuOx/CM and MnOx/CM-t catalysts. The surface of the copper mesh appeared slightly rough after pre-treatment, which conducive to the close binding between manganese oxide and the substrate. Upon further calcination, characteristic block-like and rod-like copper oxide morphologies were observed. The calcination process also improved the crystallinity of the catalyst and made the particles more regular (Fig. S2). The MnOx/CM-10 catalysts exhibited an irregular massive morphology on their surfaces. Increasing the deposition time resulted in the emergence of small nanometer-sized particles, measuring approximately 10 to 20 nm. The presence of smaller particle sizes exposed more active sites, which were highly advantageous for toluene oxidation. While there were slight differences in MnOx morphology under different electrolyte concentrations or deposition voltages, all catalysts displayed small-sized nanometer particles (Fig. S3 and Fig. S4). To confirm the elemental distribution characteristics on the catalyst surface, EDS analysis was conducted on the sample of MnOx/CM-60. In Fig. S5a, a highly uniform dispersion of Mn, Cu and O elements is revealed, and the quantitative analysis indicated that the Mn: O ratio was approximately 1:2, suggesting the possible presence of MnO2 (Fig. S5b). This was further supported by TEM and HR-TEM analysis for confirmation. The TEM image in Fig. 3 a illustrated an irregular nanostructure assembled from uniformly arranged nanoparticles. Furthermore, the HRTEM image (Fig. 3b) displays lattice fringes of 0.240 and 0.305 nm, corresponding to the MnO2 (100) and Mn3O4 (112) lattice planes, respectively, aligning well with the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 3c). Additionally, the observation of rich multiphase interfaces and abundant lattice-distorted disordered regions indicated the potential presence of oxygen vacancy defects, contributing to improve catalytic activity at low temperatures [23,45]. 3.2 Reducibility properties The reducibility of the prepared MnOx/CM samples was estimated using H2-TPR (Fig. 4 and Fig. S6). The CuOx/CM catalyst exhibited two distinct reduction peaks at 342 and 524 °C, corresponding to the consecutive reduction of Cu2+ → Cu+ → Cu0. H2-TPR spectra of all MnOx/CM-t samples showed broad shoulder peaks in the range of 200–450 °C. These features, combined with the XRD result, were primarily attributed to the coexistence of Cu and Mn in the generated CuOx and MnOx substances, mutually promoting reduction between Cu and Mn and making it challenging to distinguish their peaks [22,46]. Besides, the reduction peak located at 524 °C corresponding to Cu+ → Cu0 disappeared, which could be attributed to the inhibition of the deep reduction of CuOx by MnOx on the catalyst surface, also suggesting a interaction between the two oxides. The reduction peak around 250 °C is associated with the reduction of Mn4+ → Mn3+, while the mid-temperature reduction peak around 380 °C can be understood as the simultaneous reduction of Mn3+→ Mn2+ and Cu2+ → Cu+ [16,47,48]. With increasing deposition time, the total hydrogen consumption of catalysts gradually increased, the catalyst deposited for 60 min exhibited the highest hydrogen consumption, indicating that it contained more reducible species, which was beneficial for toluene oxidation. Similarly, the catalysts prepared with different electrolyte concentrations (Fig. S6a) and different deposition voltages (Fig. S6b) exhibited similar reduction behavior to that of MnOx/CM-t. 3.3 Surface composition analysis Fig. 5 displays the XPS spectra of Mn2p and O1s for the MnOx/CM-t catalysts, and Table. S1 represents the specific elemental valence states/oxygen species content ratios. In Fig. 5a, the Mn 2p3/2 spectrum at 642 eV can be fitted with peak splitting into three characteristic peaks centered at 643.0–644.0, 641.7–642.2, and 640.5–641.0 eV, representing Mn4+, Mn3+, and Mn2+ states, respectively [49,50]. By integrating the peak area, the Mn4+/ (Mn3++Mn2+) molar ratio was determined in the following order: MnOx/CM-60 (88.7 %) > MnOx/CM-80 (86.2 %) > MnOx/CM-40 (74.2 %) > MnOx/CM-20 (60.7 %) > MnOx/CM-10 (54.6 %) (Table. S1). Previous studies have proved that a higher percentage of high-valence manganese (Mn4+) on catalyst surface corresponds to enhanced oxidizing capability in VOCs oxidation at low temperature [20,51]. In O 1 s XPS spectrum of MnOx/CM-t samples (Fig. 5b), the peaks centered around 533, 531.4 and 529.8 eV could be ascribed to adsorbed water species (O-OH), adsorbed oxygen (Oads), and lattice oxygen (Olatt) on the surface, respectively [20,52]. Furthermore, it is evident that all samples contain a higher concentration of Olatt, which is advantageous for catalyzing toluene via the Mars-Van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [16,42,53]. The data provided in Table S1 displays that MnOx/CM-60 exhibited the highest Mn4+ content and Olatt/Oads molar ratio, indicating its potential for excellent catalytic activity. In addition, the MnOx/CM-60 catalyst exhibited a higher elemental content of Mn (Fig. S7a), indicating successful loading of Mn. The Cu2p spectrum of MnOx/CM-60 catalyst is slightly shifted towards lower binding energy compared to CuOx/CM (Fig. S7b), which is attributed to the environmental change of the Cu site [54], and further suggests the existence of interactions between Cu and Mn. 3.4 Activity tests The catalytic oxidation results (Fig. 6 a and Table S1) indicated that the CuOx/CM exhibited very low catalytic activity as expected. However, after manganese oxide was deposited, the catalytic activity increased significantly, with an extension in deposition time leading to higher surface MnOx content and improved performance. The electrolyte concentration (Fig. 6b) and deposition voltage (Fig. 6c) also affect the catalysts' performance. According to the results, when the deposition time was 60 min, the electrolyte concentration was 0.2 M, and the deposition voltage was 1.24 V, the catalyst exhibited the best toluene oxidation activity, achieving 90 % toluene conversion at 242 °C. The performance of monolithic catalysts reported in previous studies for toluene oxidation is summarized in Table S2. The 1.24–0.2-MnOx/CM-60 catalyst synthesized in this paper exhibited excellent toluene catalytic activity because of the abundance of reducible species and high Mn4+ and Olatt content, which were confirmed in the characterization results. This study provides valuable insights into the electrodeposition factors influencing the catalytic activity of monolithic catalysts, contributing to the further research and development in this field. To evaluate the practical industrial application, catalyst stability is a vital indicator for the catalysts. Fig. 7 a showed that after five cycles, the performance of 1.24–0.2-MnOx/CM-60 catalyst only slightly reduced, and T90 % remained at 254 °C. Moreover, after 44 hours of long-term experimentation, the toluene conversion rate still remained above 95 % (Fig. 7b). Furthermore, the catalytic performance of the sample was tested under the exposure of 5 % H2O (Fig. 7c). After introducing 5 % H2O into the reaction system for 5 h at 260 °C, the catalyst exhibited only a slight reduction in activity (from 96 % to 90 %). Upon stopping water addition, the catalyst's activity recovered gradually, demonstrating its excellent water resistance, and the impact of water on it is reversible. In addition, the shedding rate test was performed to evaluate the structural robustness of the monolithic catalyst, specific testing process is described in the Supporting Information. After being treated with ethanol ultrasonic delamination for 30 min, the shedding rate of catalyst samples before calcination and after calcination was 0.70 % and 0.20 %, respectively. This result indicated that the electrodeposition method firmly anchored the deposited active components to the substrate, and the calcination process caused the interaction between CuOx and MnOx, which further improved the binding force between the active component and the substrate. These findings provide crucial insights into the catalyst's performance under long-term exposure to high temperatures and water vapor, facilitating the development of more robust and durable catalysts for industrial applications. 3.5 Reaction mechanism for toluene oxidation The in-situ DRIFTS technique was employed to explore the adsorption-oxidation process of toluene on the 1.24–0.2 MnOx/CM-60 catalyst, revealing crucial intermediates in toluene oxidation and providing further clarification of the reaction pathway and mechanism. To ensure that the catalyst surface was free from any adsorbed impurities, it was pretreated with high-purity Ar at 400 °C for 30 min before the toluene adsorption reaction. The baseline spectrum was obtained after cooling the catalyst to the reaction temperature of 250 °C. Afterward, the gas introduced into the sample cell was switched to 800 ppm C7H8/Ar to start the adsorption reaction. The total gas flow rate involved in the entire adsorption-oxidation process was 50 mL·min-1. Fig. 8 a displays the time-dependent adsorption spectra on the 1.24–0.2-MnOx/CM-60 catalyst surface at 250 °C. Within the first two minutes, several bands at 3067, 1592, 1533, 1448, 1403, and 1024 cm-1 were identified. Bands at 3067 and 1024 as well as 1592 and 1448 cm-1 were connected to the typical skeletal vibrations of aromatic ring, corresponding to in-plane C-H bending vibrations and C=C stretching vibrations, respectively [20,23,55,56]. The appearance of these peaks confirmed the successful and rapid adsorption of toluene, demonstrating good adsorption property of the catalyst, which facilitate the subsequent oxidation process. The bands at 1533 and 1403 cm-1 were associated with the asymmetric and symmetric C=O stretching vibration of benzoate [13,20,55], while the bands at 1298, 1237 and 1178 cm-1 could be assigned to the C-O stretching vibration in benzyl alcohol [48,57]. The presence of benzyl alcohol and benzoate suggested the dehydrogenation of methyl group [57]. Specifically, the benzoate was formed by the removal of two hydrogen atoms in benzyl alcohol [45,57]. Even in the absence of oxygen, intermediate species such as benzyl alcohol and benzoate could still be detected in the adsorption spectra. This indicated that the presence of abundant active lattice oxygen with high mobility on the catalyst surface, actively participating in the catalytic process of toluene [58]. In particular, during the initial 10 min of the adsorption reaction, distinct bands of benzoate were detected instead of benzyl alcohol. This demonstrated that toluene was directly deep-oxidized to benzoate in the early stage, accompanied by the consumption of active oxygen species, mainly Olatt. Moreover, as the exposure time extended, the intensities of all intermediate species’ peaks increased, suggesting that they were not further oxidized and instead accumulated on the catalyst surface when there was no timely supplement of gaseous oxygen. It was also noteworthy that there were no absorption peaks ascribed to aldehydes or ketones observed during the entire toluene adsorption process. This demonstrated that the adsorbed toluene molecule was oxidized to benzyl alcohol and then rapidly oxidized in a single step to benzoate, suggesting that the catalyst possesses a strong oxidation ability and excellent catalytic activity. After adsorbing toluene for 30 mins, as described previously, the reaction gas was switched to introduce a 20 % O2/Ar mixture for oxidation (Fig. 8b). Adequate gaseous oxygen can fill the oxygen vacancies generated by the consumption of Olatt, facilitating the creation and disappearance of oxygen vacancies. The spectra of toluene oxidation exhibited slight differences compared to the adsorption, with three new spectral bands detected on the catalyst surface, which became particularly evident after 15 mins of oxygen introduction. Bands at 1308 and 1428 cm-1 indicated the formation of maleate [48,59,60], which are considered important intermediates in aromatic ring cleavage. At this point, the peak of benzoate species disappeared. Based on these observations, it could be inferred that benzoate was further oxidized to maleate under the action of gaseous oxygen. This leads to the speculation that the cleavage of C=C during the deep oxidation of benzoate to maleate may serve as the rate-determining step for the toluene catalyzed oxidation process [20,23]. Additionally, bidentate carbonate species (1568 cm-1) were detected [51], indicating that during the ultimate stages of toluene oxidation, bidentate carbonate was formed and then oxidized into CO2 and H2O. Nevertheless, bands around 2360 cm-1 were not observed, likely due to the easy desorption of CO2 [57]. In conclusion, the 1.24–0.2-MnOx/CM-60 catalyst follows the MVK mechanism during the toluene catalyzed oxidation process. The specific reaction pathway involves the initial adsorption of toluene molecules, followed by oxidation through active oxygen species (mainly Olatt) to form intermediates (benzyl alcohol and benzoate). Subsequently, gasous oxygen promotes the cleavage of the aromatic ring, and benzoate is deeply oxidized to maleate, ultimately transforming into CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusions In this work, the successful preparation of the MnOx/copper mesh monolithic catalyst using a one-step electrodeposition method demonstrates its potential for efficient toluene oxidation. The deposition parameters were systematically optimized, resulting in a catalyst with deposition time of 60 min, deposition voltage of 1.24 V, and electrolyte concentration of 0.2 M, which exhibited excellent toluene catalytic activity, achieving a T90 % of 242 °C. Characterization results proved that the high catalytic activity was attributed to its small-sized nanoparticles with high dispersion, good low-temperature reducibility, higher Mn4+ and Olatt content. Furthermore, the catalyst exhibited favorable cycle performance, water resistance, and long-term stability. In-situ DIRFTS demonstrated that the degradation pathway of toluene on the catalyst surface follows the MVK mechanism, and the breaking of the aromatic ring is a vital step during the toluene catalyzed oxidation process. In summary, the environmentally friendly and facile synthesis method used in this study resulted in a low-cost and superior performance monolithic catalyst with great potential for various applications. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic combustion is a highly efficient technology for reducing VOCs, and the development of monolithic catalysts with superior catalytic activity suitable for industrial applications is crucial. In this study, a novel MnOx/copper mesh (CM) monolithic catalyst was prepared for toluene oxidation using a one-step electrodeposition method. The effect of deposition conditions on the catalytic performance of MnOx/CM monolithic catalysts was systematically investigated by varying the deposition time, electrolyte concentration and deposition voltage. Due to good low-temperature reducibility and higher Mn4+ and Olatt content, the T50 % and T90 % of 1.24–0.2 MnOx/CM-60 catalyst could reach 229 °C and 242 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the catalyst exhibited excellent water tolerance, cycling and long-term stability. In-situ DRIFTS analysis confirmed a possible degradation pathway in which lattice oxygen in the catalyst oxidized the adsorbed toluene molecules to form intermediates (benzyl alcohol and benzoate). Subsequent replenishment of gaseous oxygen (involving oxygen vacancy creation-disappearance) led to aromatic ring breakage and the intermediates were further oxidized to maleate and finally to CO2 and H2O. This study provides a reference for the in-situ construction of low-cost metal-based monolithic catalysts for VOCs catalytic oxidation.
